you talked about your 2 step program of first consuming content and then creating it. I've been stuck on the consuming step for years, and have been wanting to go to the creating step for a while now. I've tried a bunch of different forms of creating and nothing really got me hooked... how do you decide what to create? or even determine what you're good at so you don't waste time trying to create for no reason?

for me there were always too many ways, which actually made it impossible. there were always 100 ways i 'could' just pursue a career working for someone else as a side person.  but i guess i just was too picky, and also crazy, so the only thing that made sense was to do everything myself, and there were always strong signs that that was possible because i have always picked up skills easily from a young age. but the more skills i got, the bigger and more insane the ideas and goals got. and i was just drowning and had no idea how to figure out what to do. and as time passed, it only got bigger and bigger and more insane. but i began documenting my journey early on, which sort of helped tie the entire struggle together into one cohesive story. and sure enough, after a few more chapters, and a few more layers of unmanageble expansion, just when i thought i was in way too deep to ever find my way, i just snapped and started a brute force approach which was to just start doing 5 'things' a week, ruthlessly, and never stopping, and posting it online. and then evolving the project from there, as needed, knowing that once it's underway i can surely steer it to hit every corner in due time

do you know what initially pushed you to start working on this video instead of working on songs?

yes. i was trying to do a mixed content schedule, with assorted short/medium videos, leading up to some 2min and 3min songs. but people got really really angry about the short videos, especially the 5-6 second ones. i realized i really don't even need to do those anymore. the only reason i was doing it was to keep the fans 'happy' and keep uploads happening. when i saw the rage i figured what's the point. there was also anger about 'not doing another history video' which i really don't care about, because i gotta do what i'm gonna do. but then i saw people come to my defense and say 'he only wanted to do 1 history video' that was when i realized something was wrong. the japan one was just for practice. it was not supposed to be the only one. so that's when i knew it was time to go all the way and get it over with, before moving on to the next major egg to crack, which is a regularly scheduled stream of medium / full length song releases forever

i feel like you're very quick to put the kabosh on analogous thinking, stepping in with an implication to remind the asker that the subjects in question are not entirely alike at all, and are both wonderful and terrible in their own ways. You do this with common structures for questions, as well. I have a great respect for it, because it feels like you're stopping generalization and forcing people to look even harder at things. However, I am in a cognitive science class, and it is teaching me that analogy is fairly specific to humans, and it might be what has allowed us to advance beyond other species. We can apply learned information in a highly abstract way to many facets of our lives when we recognize similar structure, whereas other animals cannot. So now I am torn! What do you make of this?

analysis, making connections, categorizing things, ... all that stuff is wonderful, and i think it's an art, not a science. you can treat it as science, but you will surely run into trouble if you ever run into jokesters

is there any way you can explain the key changes in this song https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=POfOycet4bE (except the obvious first one at 0:12)?
in general, the verses are 3 keys 'sharper' than the chorus. the verses are in Eb (or Cmin) and the chorus is in Gb (Ebmin)
it sounds like there is no key change from the chorus to the verse at 1:30-1:40 (same as 0:12-0:22)

going from the chorus to the verse, they use Eb as a pivot point, because Eb minor exists normally in Gb, and if you arrive at Ebminor but then use Eb major instead, then that sets you up to go forward in an Eb maj key (or Cmin).
but i know something weird must be going on here because of the super surprising key change at 2:23, putting it back in the same key it was at 0:12
going from the verse to the chorus they do not use that pivot point, they jump from the G7 (which sounds like it is setting up for Cmin) and immediately go to Bma7 (as b6 of the new Ebmin key)

Hey, so I've been reading music for a while now, and I feel like I can read just about anything given five-ten minutes. But now I feel like that's a hurdle to jump since people in the real world may be like "no. Are you crazy? Ten minutes doesn't exist. Play this thing now or not at all" so I'm trying excercises where I just flip to a random piece in "the real book" and play it as accurately and fast as possible. I find myself panicking and stressing myself out doing this though. So how to not panic? Or is panic is necessary to do better?    -Mr. Freak

start practicing with a metronome. take it as slow as you need so you can actually sight read it. when you run out of tunes, get another book -- try to get one with actual tempo markings so that way you can keep track of what your handicap is, relative to the song's actual tempo, and that way you can very gradually increase the tempo. also a good technique is learning to look ahead. i know that seems crazy but that is really how you get it done

What other non-car tests do you do on your songs, if any?

a typical type of test to do is just make sure you are walking around the room while listening to it, on speakers. i find this to be good practice. a lot of people sit squarely at the desk, facing the speakers the entire time, and i just think you are missing out on how the song is really going to affect someone living in the real world. so it is good to hear it while walking around, in a wide range of locations throughout the room, not just 'ground zero.' 
walking outside with headphones is also a good test. as many different systems and places as you can, is always helpful. Also, a new type of test, which unfortunately is now a reality, is the bassless test. listen to your song on a device which has fucking no bass (such as the built in speakers on a smartphone, tablet, watch, whatever.) and no, you will not hear any bass, but it may add some perspective as to how to make sure the song still stands, in a bassless world, which weirdly enough is becoming more commonplace. and yet, systems with bass are still widespread, and the game is entirely different depending on whether you have bass or not. but you need to make sure your song succeeds in both games. It's like writing a TV show, but then when you're done you have to make sure the show also makes sense if you delete one of the characters. weird, but i guess it's a fun challenge. i have actually never really done the bassless test for a song, too afraid to admit its importance. but it is important and i will do it in the future. for fucks sakes they used to make records on balls of wax, and they liked it
